Global Community • Global Commitment 44CAN IN-FLIGHT RECYCLING 
SAVE AN ENDANGERED 
SPECIES?
Our flight attendants recycle more than 10 million aluminum cans each 
year through their in-flight efforts. Heather Bell is a former flight attendant 
for American. Thanks to the interests of Heather and her fellow flight 
attendants, the endangered Tennessee purple coneflower is proposed for 
delisting from the endangered species list due to recovery — a rare event.
While American’s flight attendants were not solely responsible for this 
success, past donations from American’s flight attendant recycling program 
supported The Nature Conservancy’s (TNC) purchase of property to protect 
this flower. The recovery efforts of TNC and others funded by donors like 
American’s flight have made it possible for this flower to be considered for 
removal from the endangered species list.
Heather is now a natural resource specialist with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife 
Service, the agency responsible for the listing and recovery of endangered 
species, and was proud to share the news with her former peers. We 
thought this news would be equally interesting to readers of our CRR. 
American’s flight attendants continue their philanthropic traditions today. 
AMR is proud of the results they achieve and thanks each of them for their 
continued interest and effort.
